title-group.article-title: The Intonation and Signaling of Declarative Questions in Manchego Peninsular Spanish

author-notes.corresp: Nicholas C. Henriksen, Department of Romance Languages and Literatures, 4108 Modern Languages Building, The University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-1275, USA Email: nicholashenriksen@gmail.com

abstract.p: This paper is an experimental investigation on the tonal structure and phonetic signaling of declarative questions by speakers of Manchego Peninsular Spanish, a dialect of Spanish for which little experimental research on intonation is currently available. Analysis 1 examines the scaling and timing properties of final rises produced by 16 speakers under various pressures of tonal crowding. The quantitative results provide evidence for two contrasting nuclear pitch accent specifications: L* vs. H*. These data are consistent with the findings and analyses of final rises in Dutch, although certain time pressure effects had not been reported in this previous body of research. Analysis 2 provides a phonetic comparison of the two question contours uncovered in Analysis 1 with those of lexically and syntactically identical declarative statements. The findings indicate that speakers differentiate the two question contours from corresponding statement contours in dissimilar fashion and that for the L*H% contour, the terminal rise may be the only F0 signal of its question intent. Some speculation on the possible causes of this variation is offered in conclusion.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: This paper has two goals. The first goal is to demonstrate via experimental means that the apparent continuum of utterance-final F0 turning points in Manchego Peninsular Spanish declarative questions corresponds to two distinct tonal target specifications, and that this difference is motivated by contrasting nuclear pitch accent configurations: L* vs. H*.1,2 The proposed nuclear pitch accent contrast is shown to hold under pressures of internal tonal clash and final tonal clash, but in seemingly disparate ways. The ability for tonal contrasts to hold in such tonal pressure conditions helps to support the notion of sparse tonal specification (cf. Arvaniti & Ladd, 2009) as fundamental for understanding the linguistic expression of underlying tonal melodies. The analysis also adds to the growing body of cross-linguistic literature on variability in utterance-final rise alignment (e.g., Warren, 2005b; Warren & Daly, 2000), although most noteworthy is that final rise variability in Manchego Peninsular Spanish is motivated by differences in specification at the phonological level of analysis.

The second goal of this paper is somewhat broader in scope: to expand on recent experimental research documenting the phonetic correlates of the question vs. statement functional contrast. In doing so, it seeks to determine whether the question–statement contrast is signaled in different ways for the two declarative question contours reported here. Given that declarative questions are constrained to prosodic means to communicate their question intent, it is expected that these prosodic (i.e., intonational) means will be exploited to the maximum in the contrastive analysis conducted here. Although it is traditionally assumed that questions are differentiated from statements by a higher pitch level in the former (Bolinger, 1964, 1989; Herman, 1942; Ohala, 1984), the exact surface manifestation of this higher pitch varies across languages and from one question type to the next (Haan, 2001; van Heuven & Haan, 2000, 2002; van Heuven & van Zanten, 2005). In Analysis 2, we further investigate the question–statement contrast by comparing the phonetic details of two declarative question contours to those of lexically and syntactically identical statements. The results show that, in terms of F0 scaling, early rise contours (H*¡H%) are differentiated from statement contours on two parameters and that late rise contours (L*H%) are differentiated from statement contours on one phonetic parameter. Given these incongruent results, it is argued that communicative and situational factors must be taken into account when determining how questions are signaled in opposition to statements.

sec.title: 2 Analysis 1 – Early and late rises in Manchego Peninsular Spanish declarative question intonation
2.1 Background
sec.p: Research on question signaling indicates that declarative questions are typically marked by a higher pitch level than lexically identical statements, although the exact surface manifestation of the pitch difference varies cross-linguistically (Haan, 2001; van Heuven & Haan, 2000; van Heuven & van Zanten, 2005). It is also well known that the final boundary rise is the most recurrent prosodic characteristic used to communicate question intent for declarative questions. Importantly, the alignment of the boundary rise has been shown to exhibit a great deal of cross-linguistic variation and also within the same language, motivated by discourse-level, structural, and even sociolinguistic or pragmatic factors. Britain and Newman (1992) and Warren and Daly (2000) report that final rises in intonation-only questions in New Zealand English may begin as early as the onset of the nuclear (i.e., utterance-final stressed) syllable or as late as the onset of posttonic material. Britain (1992) also noted that pragmatic and/or group membership factors may contribute to variability in alignment of the utterance-final rise. Warren (2005b) and Warren and Daly (2000, 2005) show that speaker age and sex in addition to structural factors such as stress position also contribute to variable final rise alignment in questions. Warren in particular noted that it may be too restrictive to characterize the utterance-final rise as a steadily rising movement from the nuclear syllable. Psycholinguistic research has demonstrated further the effect of social variables such as speaker age on the perception of final rises in questions and statements in New Zealand English (Zwartz & Warren, 2003).

In Analysis 1 we examine the structure of final rises in declarative questions produced by speakers of Manchego Peninsular Spanish. Declarative questions are a unique type of question in that they are lexically and syntactically identical to their declarative statement counterpart. Whereas wh-questions, for example, are marked by lexical (and sometimes syntactic) means in addition to prosody to communicate question intent, the only way to communicate a declarative question is through intonation. In Spanish, the most common tonal configuration for declarative questions consists of a prenuclear rise followed by nuclear valley and an utterance-final rising gesture (Face, 2004, 2005; Navarro Tomás, 1944; Prieto, 2004; Quilis, 1993; Sosa, 1999) (see Figure 1a). The general consensus from this line of research is that the final rise typically occurs at the onset of posttonic material. Recent work by Willis (2004) on Dominican Spanish, however, shows that the start of the boundary rise may occur within the bounds of the nuclear stressed syllable and that this earlier rise may be accompanied by higher F0 scaling (see Figure 1b). The boundary rise is generally assumed to reflect a H% specification, due in great part to its late (i.e., posttonic) alignment, but the data reported in Willis (2004) would call this claim into question. What remains to be seen is whether final rise alignments in Spanish may be different because they are phonetic implementations of different tonal targets or because phonetic implementation rules operate on the same phonological representation in different conditions.

caption.p: Declarative question contours attested in different varieties of Spanish: Madrid Peninsular Spanish (a); Dominican Spanish (b); Miami Cuban Spanish (c); Majorcan Spanish (d).

sec.p: Other melodic patterns have been reported in the literature. Alvord (2006), for example, reported on two declarative question F0 contours produced by speakers of Miami Cuban Spanish. The most common pattern contained an utterance-final rise, similar to the contour reported in Face (2004); the second pattern contained an utterance-final fall, as shown in Figure 1c. Simonet (2008) also reported on two declarative question contours for bilingual speakers of Majorcan Spanish: a postnuclear final rising contour; and a contour comprised of a falling nuclear gesture, as in Catalan (see Figure 1d). Utterance-final falling contours have been documented for speakers of Canary Island Spanish as well (Dorta Luis, Hernández Díaz, & Díaz Cabrera, 2007, 2009). Given this cross- dialectal variability, a series of pilot studies was conducted on speakers of Manchego Peninsular Spanish. The preliminary results indicated much variability in terms of the F0 contours used to ask questions and also that many of the contours used by speakers did not seem to conform to standard accounts of Peninsular Spanish intonation (e.g., Estebas-Vilaplana & Prieto, 2010; Face, 2002a, 2008, 2011; Prieto, 2004; Quilis, 1993). The pilot data on Manchego Spanish, then, in addition to the research on intonational variation throughout the Spanish-speaking world (e.g., Prieto & Roseano, 2010; Sosa, 1999), provide sufficient motivation for a more detailed investigation of the intonational system of this little known language variety.

In Analysis 1 of this paper we examine a corpus of 795 declarative question contours, which on initial inspection do not demonstrate consistent final rise alignment. Given such variable alignment, a question that immediately arises is whether the phonetic continuum of rises reflects variation of one utterance-final rise target or if it corresponds to multiple tonal configurations. In order to determine the nature of these rises from the perspective of the autosegmental-metrical (AM) approach to intonational phonology (Beckman & Pierrehumbert, 1986; Goldsmith, 1979; Ladd, 2008; Pierrehumbert, 1980), we adhere to the notion of sparse tonal specification (Arvaniti & Ladd, 2009) as fundamental for understanding the linguistic expression of underlying tonal melodies. A common assumption in intonational research, the notion of sparse tonal specification stipulates that the factors that determine F0 may involve nothing more than interpolation from an earlier pitch target to a later one (see especially Bruce, 1977; Pierrehumbert & Beckman, 1988). Given that AM treats utterance melodies as strings of tonal events, not all syllables are required to bear tonal specifications. An advantage is that this makes possible the description of contours on long and short utterances as phonologically identical while still allowing us to model the phonetic details that result from the difference in utterance length. As will be seen in the next sections, these theoretical underpinnings were crucial for determining the phonological makeup of utterance-final rises in the Manchego corpus.

sec.title: 2.2.1 Speech materials
sec.p: The acoustic analysis was based on speech data produced in a sentence reading task designed to elicit a total of 162 test sentences via computer-based prompts. The design of the test sentences was based on 24 unique lexical combinations that contained two content words each. These lexical combinations were manipulated according to two parameters: the number of unstressed syllables between the first and second stressed syllables (i.e., interstress interval), which was 0, 1, 2, or 3; and the distance of the last stressed syllable from the end of the utterance, which was 0, 1, or 2. To exemplify, the lexical combination Nomina mi monólogo ‘S/he nominates my monologue’ has an interstress interval of 3 and a distance to end of utterance of 2. The full set of lexical combinations is given in Appendix A.3 Example sentences are provided below according to three important prosodic groupings: internal clash; final clash; and non-clash.

list-item.p: Internal clash: No unstressed syllable intervenes between the prenuclear and nuclear stressed syllables, for example, Donó mina ‘S/he donated lead.’
Final clash: No unstressed syllable follows the nuclear stressed syllable, for example, Donó maná ‘S/he donated manna.’
Non-clash: At least one unstressed syllable follows the prenuclear stressed syllable and also the nuclear stressed syllable, for example, Donó mi nómina ‘S/he donated my wages.’

sec.p: Each lexical combination was used to create two target sentence types (declarative question and declarative statement), and each target sentence was uttered twice, resulting in 96 test sentences per speaker (i.e., 24 lexical combinations × 2 sentence types × 2 repetitions). Additionally, sentences created for the (2;1) context were included two extra times per sentence type to meet protocol demands of a parallel research study.4 This resulted in 8 additional sentences, for a total of 104 test sentences read by each speaker. Distracter sentences were also included (n = 58), and these were imperatives or wh-questions, for a total of 162 sentences in the reading task. All target utterances adhered to verb-object word order, target syllables contained CV syllable structure, and target consonants were primarily sonorants or approximants.

A discourse context was created for each test sentence, and these were embedded into a Microsoft PowerPoint presentation, one discourse context and test sentence per slide. Speakers read the discourse context after the first click per slide. After the second click, speakers saw the test sentence embedded in quotation marks. For the current study, test sentences were one of two pragmatic intents: declarative statement or declarative question (see (1)). Speakers were instructed to read the discourse context in silence, but to read aloud the sentence embedded in quotes. In all cases, the discourse context was neutral (i.e., non-focal).

Participants were recorded in a quiet room by the researcher in the native dialect area. The total recording time per speaker was between 16 and 20 minutes. In Analysis 1 we focus on the data analysis protocol for declarative questions only. The protocol implemented for statements is given in Analysis 2.

sec.title: 2.2.2 Speakers and recording procedures
sec.p: Eight male and eight female speakers of Manchego Peninsular Spanish were recruited for participation in this study. Their ages were between 18 and 35, and the average age was 26. All were born and raised in the town of Socuéllamos, located in the Ciudad Real province of Castile-La Mancha, Spain (hence the gentilicium ‘Manchego’). All subjects reported that their mother and father were natives of Socuéllamos, and that the native language for both in all cases was the variety of Spanish spoken in Socuéllamos. All participants had also enrolled in (or were concurrently enrolled in) post-secondary education in Spain. Some foreign language proficiency is required for post-secondary enrollment in Spain, so no participant was truly ‘monolingual’. Subjects having lived more than 6 months abroad were not asked to participate in this study. The speech data were recorded using a SONY HI-MD MZ-RH1 minidisc recorder and a Shure WH20 head-mounted microphone.

sec.title: 2.2.3 Analysis procedures
sec.p: Duration and F0 measurements were obtained for the target productions using the computer software Praat (Boersma & Weenink, 2009). Speaker productions were manually segmented and labeled by simultaneous inspection of waveforms and wide-band spectrograms following standard segmentation criteria (see Peterson & Lehiste, 1960). F0 points presumed to represent tonal targets were also located manually. A L(ow) point was defined as an ‘elbow’ where a low level stretch turned into a clear rise. A H(igh) point was the highest F0 value of a peak from rise-fall gesture. Frequency values were extracted in Hertz and then converted to the Equivalent Rectangular Bandwidth (ERB) scale (Glasberg & Moore, 1990) before being used for statistical analysis. The conversion formula was ERB = 21.4 * log10(X * 0.00437 + 1). As has been argued elsewhere (Arvaniti & Ladd, 2009; Arvaniti, Ladd, & Mennen, 2006b; Simonet, 2008), the ERB scale gives a better approximation of the perceptual distance between F0 levels (i.e., measures of F0 magnitude) and allows more easily for the comparison of male and female data.

Tokens were discarded if they contained disfluencies, hesitation pauses, or for reasons to be detailed in the following section. The researcher also discarded utterances with long stretches of creaky voice which, as the F0 display showed, made it impossible to extract reliable measurements of turning points that were critical for the acoustic analysis. F0 and timing data were calculated using a series of Praat scripts. These data were transferred into Microsoft Excel, where F0 data were hand-checked.5 In total, 37 productions were discarded from the original corpus of 832 declarative questions, leaving 795 question utterances submitted to acoustic analysis.

Figures 2 and 3 show the F0 output of two typical utterances, early rise and late rise, respectively, together with the labels for the putative intonational targets. ‘Early’ and ‘late’ are descriptive labels that refer to the start of the utterance-final rising gesture relative to the nuclear syllable: near the nuclear onset (i.e., early within the nuclear syllable), or near the nuclear offset (i.e., late within the nuclear syllable).

caption.p: Waveform, spectrogram, and F0 for declarative question early rise contour for ¿Nomina mi monólogo? (Does s/he nominate my monologue?).
Waveform, spectrogram, and F0 for declarative question late rise contour for ¿Nomina mi monólogo? (Does s/he nominate my monologue?).

sec.p: In general, L and H turning points were defined as the F0 minimum and maximum in the relevant section of the contour, ignoring (as far as possible) any nasal-induced perturbations and obviously spurious values due to irregular voicing. L1 was taken to be the point at which the low level stretch turned into a clear rise; it was typically realized at or near the onset of the prenuclear syllable. H1 was the first High point, defined as the peak of the prenuclear rise. L2 was the second low point, or the turning point of the utterance-final rise, which is the principal focus in Analysis 1 of this paper. It should be borne in mind that ‘L2’ was a descriptive label to identify the last turning point of the utterance and did not necessarily imply that this turning point represented a tonal Low target.6 F0 data were extracted for all points, and alignment data were extracted for presumed pitch accent points (i.e., L1, H1, and L2). Finally, IT (initial tonal value) and FT (final tonal value) were defined as the lowest and highest non-spurious F0 points at the onset and the offset of the utterance, respectively. F0 data were extracted for these two points.

In order to provide an objective measure of the timing differences for the two rise types, a relative rise start score was obtained for each final rise token by dividing the temporal distance of the L2 rise start from the beginning of the nuclear stressed syllable (i.e., L2 – C1) by the total syllable duration (i.e., C2 – C1) (see Figures 4a and 4b). A rise start aligned exactly at the stressed syllable onset would receive a score of ‘0’, and a rise start aligned exactly at the stressed syllable offset would receive a score of ‘100’. For the distributional analysis, final rise tokens were organized according to prosodic manipulation context: internal clash; final clash; and non-clash.

caption.p: Early rise contour segmented for L2 (a), and late rise contour segmented for L2 (b). C1 is the nuclear onset, and C2 is the nuclear offset.

sec.p: As a check on the reliability of the measurement procedures, three turning points were remeasured four months after the initial tagging procedure had been conducted. The relative alignments for the L1, H1, and L2 points of the late rise contour were remeasured for 75 productions, or 20% of the late rise corpus. Similar reliability criteria were implemented in Arvaniti et al. (2006b).7 The absolute differences between the two sets of L1, H1, and L2 measurements were calculated, and means and standard deviations (SD) were computed. The absolute mean differences were: 2.4 ms (SD = 9.9) for L1; 2.1 ms (SD = 8.0) for H1; and 3.9 ms (SD = 9.9) for L2. Although the L2 differences may cast some doubt on the validity of the data, the overall difference (3.9 ms) was arguably minimal.8

sec.title: 2.3.1 Distributional analysis
sec.p: A number of acoustic measurements were taken to provide an objective measure of the timing and scaling differences for the two rise types. The data in Figure 5 present a distributional analysis of the relative rise start scores for all speakers in non-clash contexts. Final clash contexts are excluded there, since the lack of posttonic syllabic material creates a potential for neutralization of the early vs. late rise difference. Internal clash contexts are excluded as well, for reasons to be seen later. Recall that rise type scores were relative to the nuclear stressed syllable. As can be seen, six speakers (6F, 7F, 8F, 6M, 7M, 8M) produced final rises that typically began before the 40% point of the nuclear syllable. Their rises typically began within the first third of that syllable and in some cases began before the syllable onset. The remaining ten speakers, however, produced rises that typically began within the second half of the nuclear stressed syllable. For most speakers, the median rise start was between 90% and 100%, although the median score for two speakers (3M and 5M) was approximately 50% and their score ranges overlapped somewhat with those of the early rise speakers. We will address the productions of speakers 3M and 5M in greater detail later upon providing additional evidence on labeling them as ‘late rise’ speakers.

caption.p: Boxplot of all speaker productions according to final rise start (with respect to nuclear stressed syllable). The vertical line at ‘0’ indicates the onset of the nuclear syllable.

sec.p: The second acoustic measurement was the magnitude of tonal descent in ERB from the H1 prenuclear peak to the start of the L2 utterance-final rise (i.e., L2 – H1). The boxplot data in Figure 6 present a distributional analysis of these results for all speakers in non-clash contexts. The same two speaker groups can be inferred on the basis of these data as for the L2 alignment data. Speakers 6F, 7F, 8F, 6M, 7M, and 8M typically began the final rise at the same level of the previous peak, as indicated by ranges that were typically between -0.5 and 0 ERB. The remaining ten speakers, however, had considerably larger fall magnitudes, between -2.5 and -0.5 ERB.9

caption.p: Boxplot of all speaker productions according to magnitude of L2 descent, calculated as L2(ERB) – H1(ERB).

sec.p: Given the distributional data in Figures 5 and 6, the contours produced by speakers 6F, 7F, 8F, 6M, 7M, and 8M were labeled as ‘early rises’, and the contours produced by the remaining ten speakers were labeled as ‘late rises’. Each set of data was then submitted to further statistical analysis in which early rise productions were compared to late rise productions. In order to ensure direct comparability of L2 alignment scores, extreme outliers in the positive direction for early rise speakers and extreme outliers in the negative direction for late rise speakers were discarded.10 Based on these criteria, a total of nine productions were discarded.

sec.title: 2.3.2 Temporal alignment and F0 in non-clash and final clash contexts
sec.p: Given the informal analysis provided above, this section provides a contrastive analysis of all boundary and pitch points for the two speaker groups to determine what other phonetic and/or phonological contrasts exist, if any, between the ‘early rise’ and ‘late rise’ declarative question contours. The boundary and tonal points were: IT (initial tonal value); L1 (first Low point); H1 (first High point); L2 (second low point, or utterance-final rise turning point); and FT (final tonal value). F0 data were extracted in ERB for all points, and alignment data were extracted for pitch accent points (i.e., L1, H1, and L2).

In terms of statistical analysis, a three-way (2 × 3 × 3) fully factorial Multivariate Analysis of Variance (MANOVA) was conducted with speakergroup as a between-subjects factor and interstressinterval (isi) and distancetoutteranceend (dte) as within-subjects factors in addition to speakergroup-by-isi and speakergroup-by-dte as interaction contrasts. There were two levels of speakergroup (early risers vs. late risers), three levels of isi (1, 2, or 3 unstressed syllables), and three levels of dte (0, 1, or 2 unstressed syllables).11 The dependent variables were IT, L1, H1, L2, and FT scaling, and L1, H1, and L2 alignment. In the MANOVA, omnibus tests found overall effects for speakergroup (Wilks’ Lambda = .186, F = 315.08, p < .001), isi (Wilks’ Lambda = .548, F = 25.23, p < .001), dte (Wilks’ Lambda = .674, F = 15.72, p < .001), and the speakergroup-by-dte interaction contrast (Wilks’ Lambda = .838, F = 6.65, p < .001). No effect was found for the speakergroup-by-isi interaction contrast (Wilks’ Lambda = .968, F = 1.18, p = .27), so results for this factor will not be reported in the following sections. Results for the speakergroup-by-dte interaction will be reported in cases when it significantly affected the dependent variable in question.

sec.title: 2.3.2.1 Statistical analysis of alignment and scaling of IT and L1
sec.p: We begin by examining the scaling of IT and the L1 turning point in addition to the alignment of L1. If the early rise vs. late rise contrast is localized on the nuclear stressed syllable, it is reasonable to think that both speaker groups will behave identically on these three variables, since they reference utterance-level units not typically affected by nuclear F0 gestures. Results are presented in Table 1. Data for L1 alignment are relative scores (i.e., percentages) with respect to the onset of the prenuclear syllable.

caption.p: Scaling and alignment data for IT and L1. L1 alignment relative to prenuclear syllable.

sec.p: Early rise contours began slightly higher than late rise contours and realized the L1 slightly higher as well. Alignment of L1 for the early rise was also somewhat earlier. An ANOVA showed no significant effect for speakergroup on any of these variables: scaling of IT, F(1, 607) = .125, p = .460; scaling of L1, F(1, 607) = 1.282, p = .243; or alignment of L1, F(1, 607) = 1.509, p = .141. These results suggest that the early vs. late rise contrast does not extend to the utterance-initial or prenuclear Low tonal points.

sec.title: 2.3.2.2 Statistical analysis of alignment and F0 scaling of H1
sec.p: Next, we investigate the scaling and alignment of H1 (i.e., prenuclear peak) relative to the offset of the prenuclear stressed syllable. It will be recalled that the number of unstressed syllables between the prenuclear stressed syllable and the nuclear stressed syllable was manipulated to create four conditions, although cases of internal clash will be reported separately at a later point in this paper. If the duration and height of the prenuclear rise are conceived as invariant, it is reasonable to hypothesize that they will not be affected by isi. However, an alternative hypothesis is that isi, allowing for more time during which to realize the full potential of the prenuclear peak (cf. Elordieta, 2003; Elordieta & Calleja, 2005; Face, 2002a), will affect its duration and scaling as the number of unstressed syllables increases (cf. Arvaniti et al., 1998, 2000, 2006a, 2006b). Results are reported in Table 2. Data for H1 alignment are relative scores (i.e., percentages) with respect to the onset of the first posttonic syllable.12

caption.p: Scaling and alignment data for H1 according to isi. Alignment relative to first posttonic syllable.

sec.p: Results of the ANOVA indicate an overall effect for isi on alignment, F(2, 607) = 144.81, p < .001, but not on scaling, F(2, 607) = 2.855, p = .075. H1 mean alignment was at the midpoint of the first posttonic syllable when one unstressed syllable intervened, within the second half of the same syllable when two unstressed syllables intervened, and within the bounds of the second posttonic syllable when three syllables intervened. Follow-up post hoc tests were performed for the isi main effect, and it was shown that all levels of isi were different from one another (1 vs. 2: t = 7.65, p < .001; 1 vs. 3: t = 19.40, p < .001; and 2 vs. 3: t = 12.48, p < .001), suggesting that maximum potential of H1 alignment is not realized until three unstressed syllables intervene between the prenuclear and nuclear syllables. The fact that isi did not significantly affect the realization of peak scaling suggests that the scaling of the H1 peak is a target that speakers aim to achieve regardless of other phonetic pressures.
Next, we investigate H1 alignment and scaling as they were affected by speakergroup, reported in Table 3.

caption.p: Scaling and alignment data for H1 according to speakergroup. Alignment relative to first posttonic syllable.

sec.p: H1 for early rises had higher scaling and aligned later into the first posttonic syllable. The ANOVA showed no significant effect for speakergroup on these measures: scaling of H1, F(1, 607) = 1.383, p = .252; alignment of H1, F(1, 607) = .105, p = .901. These findings indicate that the phonetic properties of the early vs. late rise contrast do not assimilate regressively to the previous peak. The somewhat later alignment for the early rise speakers may be due to the fact that H1 was more difficult to label in this contour, since there was no clear peak before the nuclear rise.

sec.title: 2.3.2.3 Statistical analysis of alignment and F0 scaling of L2
sec.p: Next, we examine the scaling and alignment of the utterance-final rise, where alignment is understood as the rise start turning point relative to the nuclear syllable onset. We examine first the effect of the two prosodic manipulation conditions that motivated the design of the test sentences: isi and dte. Both contexts were examined since research has shown that preceding as well as following tonal targets may affect the realization of a flanked target (see, for example, Arvaniti & Ladd, 2009). Results are reported in Table 4.13

caption.p: Scaling and alignment data for L2 according to isi and dte. Alignment relative to nuclear syllable.

sec.p: The ANOVA results indicate an overall effect for isi and dte on alignment, F(2, 607) = 8.127, p < .001 and F(2, 607) = 103.239, p < .001, respectively, but no effect for either on scaling, F(2, 607) = .176, p = .839 and F(2, 607) = .049, p = .952, respectively. There were opposite trends for alignment based on manipulation condition: earlier L2 alignment as isi increased, but later L2 alignment as dte increased. Follow-up post hoc tests performed for the isi main effect on alignment revealed that rise start alignment scores were significantly different for one vs. two unstressed syllables (t = 2.34, p = .050) and for one vs. three unstressed syllables (t = 3.41, p = .002), but not for two vs. three unstressed syllables (t = 1.24, p = .425). Follow-up post hoc tests performed for the dte main effect revealed that rise start alignment scores were significantly earlier for zero vs. one unstressed syllables (t = 1.45, p < .001), for zero vs. two unstressed syllables (t = 1.65, p < .001), and for one vs. two unstressed syllables (t = 3.29, p = .003). That is, all conditions of dte were significantly different from one another.
Next, we investigate L2 alignment and scaling as they were affected by speakergroup. Results are given in Table 5.

caption.p: Scaling and alignment data for L2 according to speakergroup. Alignment relative to nuclear syllable.

sec.p: As expected, the ANOVA indicates that the early rise group had significantly higher scaling values than the late rise group, F(1, 607) = 242.55, p < .001, in addition to having significantly earlier rise start scores, F(1, 607) = 667.42, p < .001. These quantitative results, in addition to the distributional analysis of L2 alignment and scaling given in Figures 5 and 6 at the beginning of this section, provide evidence to accept the hypothesis that the rise start difference is evidence of a tonal contrast: the early rise aligned L2 higher and earlier within the nuclear syllable, whereas the late rise did so at a significantly lower level and also later within the nuclear syllable.

Finally, the speakergroup-by-dte interaction contrast ANOVA indicated an overall effect on L2 alignment, F(4, 607) = 38.79, p < .001, but not on L2 scaling, F(4, 607) = .081, p = .913. Results for L2 alignment according to speakergroup and dte are reported in Table 6.

caption.p: Alignment data for L2 according to dte and speakergroup. Alignment relative to nuclear syllable.

sec.p: The difference between speaker groups yielded significant results in all three conditions: 0 (t = 2.29, p < .001); 1 (t = 3.54, p < .001); and 2 unstressed syllables (t = 3.99, p < .001). The results for the dte = 0 condition are particularly revealing, since they indicate that the early vs. late rise contrast is preserved even in cases of extreme final tonal crowding (i.e., where no posttonic segmental material is available to execute the final rise). Further proof that early rise speakers align L2 earlier than late rise speakers is that even in dte = 2 contexts early rise speakers align L2 much earlier (17.66%) than late rise speakers in dte = 0 (31.83%).

Follow-up post hoc tests performed for the speakergroup-by-dte main effect revealed that for early rises, alignment scores were significantly different in two conditions: zero vs. one (t = 1.45, p < .001); and zero vs. two (t = 1.65, p < .001). For one vs. two, however, there was no significant difference (t = .76, p = .467). Post hoc tests performed for the late rises showed that rise start alignment scores were significantly different in all conditions: zero vs. one (t = 1.45, p < .001); zero vs. two (t = 1.65, p < .001); and one vs. two (t = 3.29, p = .003). The implication is that early rise L2 had reached maximum alignment at dte = 1, whereas late rise L2 did not do so until dte = 2.

sec.title: 2.3.2.4 Statistical analysis of scaling of FT
sec.p: The ANOVA results showed no significant effect of dte on scaling of FT, F(2, 607) = .768, p = .464. Results are reported in Table 7.

caption.p: Scaling data for FT according to dte.

sec.p: We consider the effect of speakergroup also on FT scaling. Data for scaling of FT are provided in Table 8 in addition to data for the magnitude of the final rise, which was calculated by subtracting the ERB value of the L2 point from the ERB value of the FT point.

caption.p: Scaling data for FT according to speakergroup. Also, magnitude of final rise, calculated as ERB(FT) – ERB(L2).

sec.p: The ANOVA showed that early rise contours had significantly higher FT values than late rise contours, F(2, 607) = 667.42, p < .001, an indication that the scaling of the L2 rise start difference assimilates left-to-right throughout the remainder of the utterance. As for the magnitude of the final rise, it was greater for the late rise group, and this difference was significant, F(2, 607) = 55.75, p < .001.14

Finally, the scaling of FT and all other F0 points (i.e., IT, L1 and H1, and L2) was compared to one another by means of an ANOVA for each speaker group, with tonetype (IT, L1, H1, L2, FT) as a repeated-measures factor. The purpose of this comparison was to see how the scaling of L2 compared to that of all other pitch points for the two contours. Although data for this comparison were reported in the previous sections, they are repeated in Table 9 for ease of interpretation.

caption.p: Scaling data (ERB) for IT, L1, H1, L2, and FT according to speakergroup.

sec.p: ANOVA results showed an effect of tonetype for both groups: F(4, 222) = 174.81, p < .001 for early rises; and F(4, 384) = 212.81, p < .001 for late rises. For early rises, L2 was significantly different from IT (t = 4.31, p < .001), but not statistically different from H1 (t = .90, p = .415). The effect for late rises was opposite: L2 was statistically different from H1 (t = 3.81, p < .001), but not significantly different from IT (t = .99, p = .390). These combined results indicate that the scaling of L2 was anchored to different F0 landmarks based on contour type: to the previous peak in the early rise, but to the utterance-initial F0 in the late rise.

sec.title: 2.3.3 Early vs. late rises in internal clash contexts
sec.p: This section reports on data extracted from F0 contours produced in internal clash contexts (i.e., isi = 0). Initial inspection of data produced in this context revealed an overall F0 re-configuration for early rise speakers. A sample production from an early rise speaker is provided in Figure 7a, and a sample production from a late rise speaker is provided in Figure 7b.

caption.p: F0 for declarative question for ¿Donó mina? (Did s/he donate lead?) for early rise speaker (a), and late rise speaker (b)

sec.p: The contour produced by the early rise speaker contains a continuous F0 uptrend throughout the utterance; it is impossible to label the expected peak of the prenuclear rise or the onset of the final ascent, thus H1 and L2 are not marked. The contour produced by the late rise speaker, however, consists of a rise-fall movement over the course of the two adjacent stressed syllables. H1 is realized at the nuclear onset, and L2 is realized at the nuclear offset.

In order to provide an objective measure of the differences in F0 production between the two speaker groups, F0 measurements were taken at the beginning of the nuclear syllable (i.e., C1) and also at the end of the nuclear syllable (i.e., C2). The pitch trajectory throughout this syllable was calculated by subtracting the F0 at the syllable onset from the F0 at the syllable offset (i.e., C2 – C1). This difference is presented graphically based on speaker group in Figure 8. Quantitative data are provided in Table 10.

caption.p: Boxplots of F0 difference between nuclear onset (C1) and nuclear offset (C2) in internal clash contexts. Data provided separately for early and late rise speakers
F0 data for nuclear stressed syllable in internal clash contexts based on speakergroup.

sec.p: As can be seen, early rise speakers exhibited a mean rising pitch trajectory throughout the nuclear syllable (0.77 ERB on average), whereas late rise speakers, including speakers 3M and 5M, exhibited a mean falling trajectory (-0.82 ERB on average). Results of a t-test showed this difference to be significant (t = 3.41, p < .001).

A final point worth consideration, given the late rise production in Figure 7b, is whether the scaling of L2 is undershot (i.e., higher scaling) due to tonal crowding in cases of extreme tonal pressure (cf. Arvaniti & Ladd, 2009, p. 63; Ladd, 2008; Prieto, 2005). Given that the L2 turning point was accessible for labeling in internal clash contexts for late rises only and that this L point was flanked by two H points, a question that arises is whether L2 was susceptible to tonal undershoot in cases of extreme tonal crowding. Data are reported in Table 11. The mean value of L2 is given per isi condition.

caption.p: L2 Scaling data based on isi (late rise speakers only).

sec.p: The ANOVA showed no significant effect for isi on L2 scaling, F(1, 501) = .044, p = .630, indicating that L2 was not undershot by late rise speakers in this context of extreme tonal crowding.

sec.title: 2.4 Summary and discussion
sec.p: Significant differences were not found between speaker groups on utterance-initial and prenuclear alignment and scaling measures; these results provide strong evidence that group differences observed upon initial inspection of the final rise corpus (i.e., early vs. late rise) were localized after the onset of the nuclear syllable. Regarding L1 alignment, the number of utterance-initial unstressed syllables was fixed before the prenuclear syllable, limiting our ability to provide direct AM implications. In terms of H1 alignment, this peak aligned later as the number of intervening unstressed syllables increased. Specifically, when one or two unstressed syllables intervened, H1 aligned within the first posttonic syllable. When three unstressed syllables intervened, H1 aligned within the second posttonic syllable (on average). Given the general assumption in the AM model that a tone is understood to be not starred if it is the more loosely aligned of two tonal targets with respect to a stressed syllable edge (cf. Arvaniti et al., 1998, 2000; Face, 2002a; Grice, 1995; Ladd, 2000), we can infer that the loose posttonic alignment of H1 under varying levels of tonal pressure warrants a trailing tone specification, thus, a L*+H rising accent, similar to Face (2002a) for Madrid Spanish. The L+H* alternative may be dismissed since L1 was coincident with the stressed syllable in most cases, whereas for H1 this was clearly not the case.15

As for L2 scaling and alignment, the early rise and late rise were shown to differ on the two phonetic dimensions known to characterize tonal targets within the AM framework: F0 scaling and temporal coordination with the segmental string. As for scaling, early rises began at approximately the same level of the previous peak, whereas late rises began at approximately the same level of the initial tonal value; early rises were also shown to have a higher final tonal value. As for alignment, early rise L2 never surpassed the 40% point in non-clash contexts, whereas late rise L2 was typically obtained within the second half of the nuclear stressed syllable, and in many cases was coincident with the onset of postnuclear material. The timing contrast was shown to hold even in cases of final tonal clash where the lack of posttonic segmental material might be expected to obscure the early vs. late rise start time difference. Another indication that contrasting tonal specifications triggered the different rise starts was found in speaker responses to internal clash. Response differences in tonal clash contexts are typically assumed to indicate differences in tonal specifications (Face, 2002a; Prieto, 2005; Silverman & Pierrehumbert, 1990), and the divergent F0 gestures that were observed here are further motivation to assume that a phonological contrast exists.

Given these findings, we posit the following nuclear pitch accent specifications: H* for early rises and L* for late rises. Following the notion of sparse tonal specification (Arvaniti & Ladd, 2009), we assume that the tonal plateau or the minor F0 descent from the prenuclear peak to the L2 point in the early rise was a consequence of phonetic interpolation, or F0 sag between flanking H tone specifications (Elordieta, 2003; Elordieta & Calleja, 2005; Ladd & Schepman, 2003; Pierrehumbert, 1980). Crucially, this sagging transition could not be observed in internal clash contexts.16 The tonal descent after H1 in late rise contours, however, and most notably in internal clash contexts, provides evidence for a nuclear L* specification between the prenuclear H and the final H%. Cross-linguistic evidence on the L* vs. H* contrast has been found elsewhere in the AM literature. Specifically, Gussenhoven and Rietveld (2000) and Haan (2001) investigated such a contrast in Dutch, referring to L* vs. H* as ‘low rise’ vs. ‘high rise’, respectively. Similar to the findings of the proposed H* accent discussed here, Haan (2001, p. 112) referred to the H*H% melody as: “following the high F0 target on the [preceding] accent, pitch remained level for a brief stretch; from this high target, the final rise took off”. As for L*H%, Haan noted an F0 valley after the preceding peak, and then a posttonic rise. Such an analysis would also seem to be in line with the current data.17

The significantly higher FT level in the early rise contour is analyzed as upstepped ¡H%, or left-to-right phonetic raising of the final tonal level due to the preceding nuclear H* accent. Whereas ‘upstep’ has been understood elsewhere to form part of the specification of an affected tone (e.g., Truckenbrodt, 2002; Willis, 2006/7), this view would seem to differ from that of Nibert (2000), for example, who claims that some ‘trigger’ raises the level of an upstepped tone.18 The current analysis adopts the view of Nibert (2000) who interprets upstep as contextual phonetic raising due to a previous H specification, that is, the higher final F0 in the early rise is purely phonetic and does not communicate a contrast with H% of the late rise.19 The schematic in Figure 9 is a visual representation of the proposed tonal specifications for the early and late rise contours.

caption.p: Schema of early and late rise contours compared, with proposed tonal specifications. Early rise is indicated by dotted configurations, and late rise is indicated by solid configurations. The shaded columns indicate stressed syllables.

sec.p: A number of comments are in line on how the results speak to broader issues of autosegmental prosodic structure. The experimental data provide strong evidence that adjustments for tonal crowding can systematically and significantly affect the realization of intonation contours. In both question contours, H1, for example, aligned significantly later into posttonic segmental material as isi increased. Although research on tonal crowding effects typically shows that tonal targets remain stable once tones are more than two syllables apart (e.g., Arvaniti et al., 1998, 2000, 2006a), the current findings demonstrate that alignment of the prenuclear peak is variable when up to three unstressed syllables intervene. As for the L2 point, its alignment was affected by tonal crowding as well, but from preceding and following prosodic contexts, corroborating the general finding that F0 timing may be affected by pressure from two adjacent tones. In terms of scaling, the data replicate previous findings that the F0 of H targets is not significantly affected by tonal crowding pressures (Arvaniti & Ladd, 2009; Arvaniti et al., 1998, 2000, 2006a; Face, 2002b; Prieto, 2005). Somewhat unexpectedly, L2 for late rise speakers was not undershot in the internal clash context. Arvaniti and Ladd (2009) are clear on the evidence for L undershooting when in contact with flanking H tones, but the current study could not replicate this finding. The ability for the L2 point to remain constant in the Manchego late rise corpus makes for a stronger case that the tone that associates with the stressed syllable is Low. As a final consideration, it remains to be seen whether frameworks of intonational phonology that mark all syllables (stressed and unstressed) with unique specifications may provide better insight into this cross-linguistic inconsistency. One model that comes to mind is the Parallel Encoding and Target Approximation Model (PENTA) developed by Xu (2005) and Xu and Xu (2005). Future work should investigate the compatibility of PENTA and AM given the present data.

A next question that arises is how the early and late rise contours compare to and are signaled differently from contours produced for lexically identical declarative statements. Given the scaling difference that was observed on the nuclear syllable (i.e., higher F0 in early rises), it is of interest to examine how these different tonal levels compare to those of declarative statements. In Analysis 2 we follow up on this point.

sec.title: 3 Analysis 2 – The acoustic correlates of statement vs. question intonation in Manchego Peninsular Spanish
3.1 Background
sec.p: As mentioned previously, the most recurrent prosodic characteristic used to communicate question intent is high pitch, either locally or globally (Haan, 2001, p. 214; van Heuven & van Zanten, 2005). Examples of local marking include an utterance-initial higher pitch level or an utterance-final rising gesture. Examples of global marking include an overall raised register level or the suspension of downtrends normally exhibited in statements. Van Heuven and van Zanten (2005) note that although the boundary rise may be the most widespread prosodic marker of question intent across languages, it is not typically the only F0 correlate of question intent. Other phonetic signals of interrogativity include the size of utterance-initial vs. utterance-final accents and the slope of the baseline connecting Low turning points of accents (van Heuven & Haan, 2002). Later alignment of peaks in questions (50–75 ms) is another indicator of interrogativity (D’Imperio & House, 1997; House, 2002, 2003).

As for Spanish, one recurrent claim is that questions are signaled by a higher tonal level from the onset of the utterance (Cunningham, 1983; Navarro Tomás, 1944; Quilis, 1993; Sosa, 1999). Navarro Tomás describes the intonation of questions as having a high tone at the beginning of the utterance which then descends gradually until it reaches the penultimate syllable. Experimental work has shown that it is actually the scaling of the prenuclear peak, with a higher value in questions, that signals this difference (Alvord, 2006; Face, 2004, 2007, 2008; Prieto, 2004; Sosa, 1999). Results from perception experiments have also corroborated this general finding (Face, 2005, 2007), although Face (2007) shows that the prenuclear peak difference is not the only non-final cue that listeners use to perceive the question–statement contrast. Willis (2006/7), in an analysis of Dominican Spanish intonation, noted that the most robust F0 difference between questions and statements was at the nuclear syllable, with higher F0 in questions.

Face (2007) highlights four ways in which the intonation of declarative statements differs from that of lexically identical declarative questions for speakers of Peninsular Spanish. First, the initial accentual peak is higher in questions. Second, in medial position, statements exhibit an F0 rise, whereas questions contain no such accentual peak. Third, on the nuclear syllable, questions have flat F0 whereas statements have an F0 rise (or sustained pitch). Finally, there is a posttonic rise to the end of the utterance in questions, but an utterance-final fall in statements. These differences are depicted in schematic form in Figure 10.

caption.p: Schematic of Madrid Peninsular Spanish declarative statement (a) vs. declarative question (b) contours compared (adapted from Face, 2007).

sec.p: For Analysis 2, we will not be able to determine the potential for differences in utterance-medial position as all target utterances contained two content words only. We will consider, however, whether F0 differences are observed at various non-final and final pitch points, and this will help to provide a detailed account of how the question–statement contrast is signaled in Manchego Spanish.

sec.title: 3.2.1 Speech materials and speakers
sec.p: Two separate but identical analyses were conducted for Analysis 2. For each declarative question corpus (i.e., early rise and late rise), the alignment and scaling properties of five pre-determined F0 points were compared to those of declarative statements produced by the respective speaker groups. In total 784 statement productions were submitted to acoustic analysis: early rise speakers produced 294 declarative statements; late rise speakers produced 490 declarative statements. A total of 48 statement productions were discarded. These contained disfluencies, hesitation pauses, or long stretches of creaky voice.

sec.title: 3.2.2 Analysis procedures
sec.p: Duration and F0 measurements were obtained for the target statement productions using the computer software Praat (Boersma & Weenink, 2009). F0 points thought to represent tonal targets were located manually. Frequency values were extracted in Hertz and then converted to the ERB scale. Figures 11 and 12 show the displays of two typical utterances: a statement produced by an early rise speaker; and a statement produced by a late rise speaker, respectively. Although two speaker groups could be identified based on declarative question intonation (i.e., early rise vs. late rise, see Analysis 1), all speakers produced the same sequence of melodic gestures for declarative statements: an initial rise with fixed valley at the prenuclear onset and trailing peak past the stressed syllable offset; a descent to a sustained level F0 (or reduced rise) on the nuclear syllable; and utterance-finally, a lower F0 value. As for labeling, L1 was defined as the first Low point; it was typically realized near the onset of the prenuclear stressed syllable. H1 was the first High point, corresponding to the peak of the same rise. L2 was the second low point which typically began a plateau or a reduced rise on the nuclear stressed syllable.20 F0 data were extracted for all points, and alignment data were calculated for prenuclear pitch accent points (i.e., L1 and H1). Finally, IT (initial tonal value) and FT (final tonal value) were defined as the lowest non-spurious F0 points at the onset and the offset of the utterance, respectively. F0 data were extracted for these two points as well.

caption.p: Waveform, spectrogram, and F0 for declarative statement Nomina mi monólogo (S/he nominates my monologue) by early rise speaker.
Waveform, spectrogram, and F0 for declarative statement Nomina mi monólogo (S/he nominates my monologue) by late rise speaker.

sec.title: 3.3.1 Early rise speakers: Declarative statements vs. declarative questions
sec.p: We begin with a phonetic comparison of declarative statements and declarative questions produced by early rise speakers, recalling from Analysis 1 that six speakers comprised this group: 6F, 7F, 8F, 6M, 7M, and 8M. Internal clash data were not examined for either sentence type, as the contours produced by early rise speakers in this context could not be labeled for H1 and L2 (see Analysis 1). As for the statistical analysis, a one-way fully factorial Multivariate Analysis of Variance (MANOVA) was conducted with sentencetype (statement vs. question) as a within-subjects factor. The dependent variables were IT, L1, H1, L2, and FT scaling, and L1 and H1 alignment. In the MANOVA, the omnibus test found an overall effect for sentencetype (Wilks’ Lambda = .097, F = 361.33, p < .001).

The boxplots in Figure 13 represent the full distribution of L1 and H1 alignment scores, respectively. As can be seen, both points aligned later in questions. Mean alignment for L1 was 17.72% (SD = 13.68) for statements and 24.70% (SD = 19.22) for questions. For H1 it was 56.40% (SD = 36.48) for statements and 99.88% (SD = 57.88) for questions.21 The difference was significant for H1, F(1, 432) = 60.20, p < .001, but not for L1, F(1, 432) = .548, p = .460. Although a significant effect was found for sentencetype on H1 alignment, the boxplot in Figure 13b indicates that there was considerable overlap in the two distributions.

caption.p: Boxplots of declarative question early rise vs. declarative L1 alignment (a) and H1 alignment (b). L1 alignment is relative to the prenuclear syllable, and H1 alignment is relative to the first posttonic syllable. The vertical line at ‘0’ indicates the onset of the prenuclear syllable in (a) and the onset of the first posttonic syllable in (b).

sec.p: Scaling data were also compared for each turning point, and boxplot diagrams are provided in Figure 14. These figures show that for all speakers, F0 data were fairly comparable on the first three phonetic points (i.e., IT, L1, H1), but not on the last two (i.e., L2 and FT).

caption.p: Boxplots of declarative statement vs. declarative question scaling comparison for 5 pitch points for all speakers in the early rise group. The pitch points are: IT (a); L1 (b); H1 (c); L2 (d); and FT (e).

sec.p: Quantitative data for this same information are reported in Table 12. The ANOVA found no statistical difference for scaling of IT, F(1, 432) = .548, p = .460, no statistical difference for scaling of L1, F(1, 432) = .991, p = .370, no statistical difference for scaling of H1, F(1, 432) = 1.765, p = .322, statistically higher L2 scaling in questions, F(1, 432) = 73.83, p < .001, and statistically higher FT scaling in questions, F(1, 432) = 627.18, p < .001. That is, two scaling differences were found between the question and statement contours for the early rise group, and these were at the L2 and FT pitch points.

caption.p: Scaling comparison for IT, L1, H1, L2, and FT for early rise speakers based on sentencetype.

sec.title: 3.3.2 Late rise speakers: Declarative statements vs. declarative questions
sec.p: The same phonetic comparisons were carried out for the late rise speaker group. We recall from Analysis 1 that ten speakers comprised this group: 1F, 2F, 3F, 4F, 5F, 1M, 2M, 3M, 4M, and 5M. A one-way fully factorial Multivariate Analysis of Variance (MANOVA) was conducted with sentencetype (statement vs. question) as a within-subjects factor. In the MANOVA, the omnibus test found an overall effect for sentencetype (Wilks’ Lambda = .162, F = 463.38, p < .001).

The boxplots in Figure 15 represent the full distribution of L1 and H1 alignment scores, respectively. Similar to what was reported earlier, L1 and H1 aligned later in questions than in statements. Mean alignment for L1 was 24.56% (SD = 24.45) for statements and 29.62% (SD = 29.19) for questions; for H1 it was 62.87% (SD = 37.97) for statements and 77.44% (SD = 47.21) for questions. The difference was significant for H1, F(1, 744) = 26.670, p < .001, but not for L1, F(1, 744) = 3.282, p = .212. Although a significant effect was found for sentencetype on H1 alignment, the boxplot in Figure 15b indicates that there was considerable overlap in the two distributions.22

caption.p: Boxplots of declarative question late rise vs. declarative L1 alignment (a) and H1 alignment (b). L1 alignment is relative to the prenuclear syllable, and H1 alignment is relative to the first posttonic syllable. The vertical line at ‘0’ indicates the onset of the prenuclear syllable in (a) and the onset of the first posttonic syllable in (b).

sec.p: A comparison of scaling data was conducted as well, and these results are provided in boxplot format in Figure 16. These figures show that for all speakers, F0 data were fairly comparable on the IT, L1, H1, and L2 points, but not on the FT point.

caption.p: Boxplots of declarative statement vs. declarative question scaling comparison for 5 pitch points for all speakers in the late rise group. The pitch points are: IT (a); L1 (b); H1 (c); L2 (d); and FT (e).

sec.p: Quantitative data were tabulated as well and are provided in Table 13. The ANOVA found no statistical difference for scaling of IT, F(1, 744) = 1.615, p = .204, no statistical difference for scaling of L1, F(1, 744) = 3.385, p = .139, no statistical difference for scaling of H1, F(1, 744) = .088, p = .767, no statistical difference for scaling of L2, F(1, 744) = 1.299, p = .255, and statistically higher FT scaling in questions, F(1, 744) = 1123.614, p < .001. That is, the only scaling difference between the late rise question contour and the statement contour was at the FT point.

caption.p: Scaling comparison for IT, L1, H1, L2, and FT for late rise speakers based on sentencetype.

sec.title: 3.4 Summary and discussion
sec.p: In Analysis 2, two comparisons were carried out: early rise declarative questions vs. declarative statements; and late rise declarative questions vs. declarative statements. H1 aligned later in questions than statements for both groups, and the differences were significant. Distributional analysis of these data, however, showed much overlap between the respective distributions. The peak alignment difference attested in House (2002, 2003) for Swedish, for example, was more robust (50–75 ms) than was attested here. Whether or not the smaller alignment differences uncovered in the present data prove to be relevant in a perception-based framework, as was confirmed by House, is left for future investigation.

More revealing were the findings on F0 scaling. No significant differences were found for either comparison on IT, L1, or H1, indicating that questions and statements were signaled at comparable F0 levels at the utterance-initial and prenuclear pitch points for both speaker groups. At the L2 point, early rise speakers exhibited higher F0 in questions, whereas late rise speakers did not. The scaling of FT was significantly higher in questions for both groups. The schematics in Figure 17 are a visual representation of these scaling differences.

caption.p: Schematics of declarative question and declarative statement contours compared: early rise question contour vs. statement (a); late rise question contour vs. statement (b). Question contours are indicated by solid configurations, and statement contours are indicated by dotted configurations. The shaded columns indicate stressed syllables.

sec.p: Higher nuclear scaling in addition to higher FT scaling in declarative questions, as shown here for the early rise group, has been reported elsewhere in the experimental literature on Spanish. Specifically, Willis (2006/7) made the claim for a scaling contrast on the nuclear accent in Dominican Spanish, showing that the F0 level for this accent was between 77% and 200% higher for questions than statements. The results reported for Dominican Spanish and the results reported here for Manchego Peninsular Spanish are combined evidence that the non-final indicator of question intent in Spanish may be signaled as late as the nuclear syllable. What could not be corroborated in the current results was higher H1 peak in questions, as in Face (2004, 2005, 2007) for Madrid Spanish and Alvord (2006) for Miami Cuban Spanish. One possible explanation for this discrepancy is that declarative questions in Spanish may exhibit higher F0 at either of two non-final points in Spanish (i.e., the prenuclear peak or the nuclear accent), and that the factor governing this variability is the language variety that one speaks.23 Dialect variation in intonation has been widely attested elsewhere in the cross-linguistic literature (e.g., Arvaniti & Gårding, 2007 for American English; Atterer & Ladd, 2004 for German; Dalton & Ní Chasaide, 2005 for Irish; Elordieta & Calleja, 2005 for Basque Spanish; Fletcher, Grabe, & Warren, 2005 for English; see also Warren, 2005a for review) and in the literature on Spanish as well (e.g., Prieto & Roseano, 2010; Sosa, 1999). The present Manchego data add to this body of work by showing that different dialects of a language may vary not only in how they align peaks or valleys, but also in how they realize the question–statement contrast.

Another issue is how to deal with results obtained for the late rise speaker group, and an important question is why final scaling differences were observed at the utterance-final position only. One possible explanation may have to do with the meanings associated with the two question contours, and for this, we turn to the results of Henriksen (2010). Specifically, Henriksen compared the frequency with which speakers produced early and late rise contours in a sentence reading task (as reported in Analysis 1, above) with the frequency that the same speakers produced questions in an interactive dialogue game performed in pairs. The 16 speakers analyzed in the current paper produced data under both speaking conditions. The findings were the following: the late rise predominated in the reading data; the early rise predominated in the dialogue data; and whenever a speaker style-shifted between tasks, the shift was from the late rise in the reading task to the early rise in the dialogue task.24 Henriksen’s claim was that variable use of the boundary rise was a stylistically-motivated feature of Manchego intonation; based on these findings, we would like to suggest that the lower communicative demands of read speech (i.e., there is no listener when one reads text from a computer screen) motivate the neutralization of phonetic cues that signal certain pragmatic contrasts, such as ‘question’ vs. ‘statement’. In the case of the late rise contour, utterance-final signals of interrogativity were present, but early signals were lost, and the neutralization of these earlier signals may result from the fact that the late rise contour is used primarily when speakers are reading aloud a prepared text. The early rise, inferred as a ‘semi-spontaneous’ or ‘conversational’ pattern, was shown here to differ from its statement counterpart at two phonetic points, and this may be so because the need to signal question intent is greater when an interlocutor is present.

Indeed, such a claim relies on the assumption that speakers are highly aware of the listening and situational conditions in which they speak. As noted in Baker and Bradlow (2009, p. 394), “when speakers believe their listeners might have difficulty perceiving their speech, they usually try to speak more clearly by ‘globally’ hyper-articulating”. Uchanski (2005) notes as well that ‘clear speech’ is adopted when one speaks in difficult communication situations. When speakers utter declarative questions, they know that their listeners must rely on intonational cues only to understand the pragmatic meaning of their intended message. It would not be unexpected, then, to observe hyper-articulation of F0 signals of interrogativity in speaking situations in which a listener is physically present, and this may explain why the early rise contains more F0 cues of question intent than the late rise. As a caveat, there is Uchanski’s observation that higher F0 levels and larger F0 range in clear speech situations may be an extraneous by-product of vocal effort due to increased hyper-articulation. In Analysis 2 we have not provided quantitative data for other phonetic measurements (e.g., speaking rate) that are typically examined in research on speech style (see Smiljanic & Bradlow, 2009 for review). These issues are clearly relevant to how questions are hyper- or hypo-articulated, but must be left for future research.

sec.title: 4 Conclusion
sec.p: This paper was guided by two research goals. The first goal was to provide empirical evidence on the continuum of utterance-final rises in Manchego Peninsular Spanish declarative questions and to determine if this variability was motivated by one or two tonal target specifications. As the results showed, the apparent continuum of utterance-final F0 turning points corresponds to two distinct tonal target specifications, and this difference is indicated by contrasting nuclear pitch accent configurations: L* vs. H*. The timing contrast held even in cases of final tonal clash where the lack of posttonic segmental material might be expected to neutralize the rise start time difference. Time pressure effects led to gestural re-organization in the internal clash context for the early rise group, providing further evidence that contrastive tonal specifications triggered the different rise starts. The clearest implication of these findings is that researchers on Spanish intonation cannot assume that utterance-final rises may be triggered by H*¡H% or L*H% only for speakers of a particular language variety. While both patterns have been reported elsewhere in Spanish, they have not been reported to coexist in the same variety, so the findings of this paper present a previously unreported type of variation. The results also speak to broader cross-linguistic issues on the phonetics and phonology of the boundary rise (cf. Britain, 1992; Gussenhoven & Rietveld, 2000; Haan, 2001; Warren, 2005a; Warren & Daly, 2000, 2005; Zwartz & Warren, 2003). Specifically, the issue of F0 re-organization in time pressure contexts had not been reported in this previous body of research.

The second research goal was broader in scope, investigating whether the question–statement functional contrast was signaled in the same way for speakers who produce the H*¡H% early rise contour vs. those who produce the L*H% late rise contour. Results showed two scaling differences in the early rise vs. statement comparison, but one scaling difference in the late rise vs. statement comparison. The findings for early rise speakers were in line with cross-linguistic research on the question–statement contrast, as the early rise contour differed from the statement contour on non-final as well as on final F0 points. The anomalous finding that fewer phonetic markers differentiated questions from statements for late rise speakers was attributed to the stylistic meaning of the late rise contour and the lesser communicative demand that read speech patterns may have. The multiple F0 signals of question intent in the early rise were understood as hyper-articulation of interrogativity signals in speaking situations in which a listener is present. Unfortunately, this effect could not be addressed in full and must be left for more thorough examination in future research.
