caption.p: L2 alignment based on combinations of ISI and DTE.

ack.p: This paper is a revised and updated version of Chapter 4 of my dissertation Question Intonation in Manchego Peninsular Spanish, directed by Erik Willis and Dan Dinnsen at Indiana University. I am indebted to my co-directors as well as to Ken de Jong and Kim Geeslin of the same institution. I am also especially grateful to Associate Editor Paul Warren and reviewers Gorka Elordieta and Tim Face for their constructive feedback on earlier drafts of this manuscript. This paper has also benefited from comments from Amalia Arvaniti, Lorenzo García-Amaya, Miquel Simonet, and audience members of Speech Prosody 2010 held in Chicago, IL. Finally, many thanks to Stephanie Dickinson and Bill Wyatt for help with the statistical analysis.

fn.p: Speakers of Manchego Peninsular Spanish reside in the Castile-La Mancha autonomous community located in south-central Spain. The Castile-La Mancha region borders Madrid to the north, Andalusia to the south, Extremadura to the west, and Valencia to the east. The variety of Spanish spoken in Castile-La Mancha is generally considered Castilian or Peninsular Spanish, spoken in the central and northern regions of mainland Spain.

‘Declarative question’ in this paper refers to information-seeking questions for which two responses are possible (i.e., positive (yes) or negative (no)) and for which there are no formal markers of interrogativity. Note that the term ‘yes/no question’ may be appropriate as well from a pragmatic standpoint, although yes/no questions in many Germanic languages are marked by inversion (Haan, 2001, p. 12; van Heuven & Haan, 2000, 2002) and there is debate as to whether declarative questions are truly information-seeking or confirmation-seeking in these languages (Haan, 2001, p. 16). Since many of the hypotheses in this paper were motivated by the identical lexico-syntactic structure of the statements and questions in the test sentences, the term ‘declarative question’ was chosen. It is important to bear in mind that the information-seeking intent of the questions analyzed in this study would seem to be the pragmatic equivalent of yes/no questions in Germanic languages.

The primary motivation for the two prosodic manipulation conditions was to help determine which putative tonal targets were undershot and/or temporally displaced under varying degrees of tonal crowding. Tonal crowding effects follow from the fact that the phonetic alignment realization of a particular target tone adjusts in the presence of adjacent tones but remains stable once tones are more than two syllables apart (Arvaniti & Ladd, 2009; Arvaniti et al., 1998, 2000, 2006a). As will be seen later, the particular phonetic effects that were produced in different contexts of tonal crowding were especially helpful for determining the phonological nature of certain F0 elbows under analysis.

For this paper, the (X;Y) convention will be used to refer to particular prosodic manipulation contexts. ‘X’ refers to interstress interval, and ‘Y’ refers to the number of unstressed syllables after the nuclear syllable.
F0 data that were ‘pitch-halved’ (i.e., where the actual F0 value was divided in half upon output from Praat) were hand-checked and corrected by examining the original F0 productions in Praat.
In fact, as will be demonstrated later, L2 corresponded to a High target in early rise productions, but a Low target in late rise productions.

Amalia Arvaniti (personal communication) notes that such reliability checks have thus far been implemented to test the labeling of L valleys and not H peaks. Given the current findings, it may be that more variability is found in the hand labeling of H maxima than L minima, and this may have to do with H peaks that were not always clear inflections. For further discussion on pitch span in intonational peaks, see Knight and Nolan (2006).

It should also be noted that Arvaniti and Ladd (2009) employed algorithmic determination in addition to eye estimation of F0 elbows and found that the two methods did not lead to substantially different conclusions.
Note that the smaller L2 descent for early rises is due to a higher L2 value and not a lower H1 value (when compared to late rises). For more specific details, see Tables 3 and 5.

An extreme outlier was defined as a case with a value more than three times the height of its box (or its interquartile range). Extreme outliers are marked with asterisks (*) in the boxplots in Figures 5 and 6. It was decided that a metric needed to be devised to account for the fact that speakers may have produced multiple declarative question contours (i.e., late rise tokens for some, but early rise tokens for others) in the same task.
Recall that there were four levels of isi (0, 1, 2, and 3 unstressed syllables) in the original design. However, productions of isi = 0 were analyzed separately.
We combine early rise and late rise data in Table 2 since the MAVOVA indicated no effect for the speakergroup-by-isi interaction contrast. The same applies for the data reported in Tables 4 and 7.
For a more complete analysis of the effect of all combinations of isi and dte on L2 alignment, see Appendix B.

It is worth noting that the ERB differences in FT scaling (0.80 ERB) and final rise magnitude (0.54 ERB) between the two speaker groups were very close to the minimum difference in ERB considered to be perceptible (0.50 ERB) (Colantoni & Gurlekian, 2004, p. 113; see also discussion in Moore, 2010, pp. 474–475). In future research it would be necessary to carry out a perception experiment to determine whether these differences are perceived or not.

It is worth mentioning that given the claims of Face and Prieto (2006/7), the L*+H accent posited here would be analyzed as L+H* (or L+>H* in Estebas Vilaplana and Prieto, 2008). An issue that remains, assuming this alternative analysis, is that Face and Prieto claim a categorical difference between an early rising accent with a delayed peak (observed here) and a late rising accent with a prenuclear valley until the end of the tonic syllable. As observed in this paper, there was considerable variation in L1 alignment: the late rise mean L1 alignment score was 29.27 with a standard deviation of 29.19, implying that the L1 point in some cases was beyond the midpoint of the tonic syllable. A more thorough investigation of L1 alignment under varying degrees of tonal crowding must be left for future research.

Sagging transitions are posited as F0 sags (i.e., minimal F0 descent) between two H accents. They are understood as phonetic interpolation between two H tones and do not warrant L tone specifications; the sagging transition model was first posited in Pierrehumbert (1980). For further discussion, see Ladd and Schepman (2003) or Pierrehumbert and Beckman (1988).

It is worth noting that some accounts of H* note that the phonetic implementation of this accent is a clear peak during the metrically strong syllable (for example, Beckman, Díaz-Campos, McGory, & Morgan, 2002). As noted in Pierrehumbert (1980), the main difference between H* and L*+H or L+H* is that the latter show a rise from a low point, which is lacking in H*. See also Arvaniti and Gårding (2007). Also, this is not the first AM analysis of the early vs. late rise contrast in Spanish declarative question intonation. In fact, Sosa (1999) distinguishes two declarative question final rise types in Peninsular Spanish (i.e., early vs. late) as L+H*H% and L*H%, respectively. An advantage to Sosa’s L+H* analysis for the early rise is that it captures the upward turning point near the onset of the nuclear syllable, which is consistent with a L tone in that location. Note that under the current analysis of H* we might expect a longer high plateau throughout the nuclear syllable, given that the preceding tone is also H. A drawback to Sosa’s alternative – taking into account especially the alignment data presented here – is that the leading L tone of the putative L+H* accent was not shown to surface as such in the early rise data. In fact, if the rise start were reflective of a leading L, one would expect its alignment to be variable under different contexts of tonal pressure. As has been documented here, the alignment of early rise L2 was fixed at the onset of the nuclear syllable, and this is not expected for an unstarred L. Whichever analysis is ultimately adopted (i.e., L+H* or H*), the important point is that the early rise contour contrasts phonologically with the late rise contour.

Truckenbrodt (2002) refers to upstep as a return to the initial F0 height due to association to the intonation phrase, assuming the existence of F0 register levels which act as phonological anchoring points for subsequent tonal events. This phenomenon would seem to be different from the overall higher F0 of the FT in the early rise contour observed here. The reader should keep in mind that although ‘upstep’ generally refers to higher F0 level, there are multiple interpretations in the AM literature (see, for example, Estebas Vilaplana & Prieto, 2008). For further information on the incorporation of pitch scaling in AM theory, see Face (2011).
In a similar fashion, Beckman and Ayers Elam (1997) analyze utterance-final mid-level F0 in English as a L% that is upstepped by preceding H-. For further discussion, see Beckman et al. (2002).
See Face (2002a) and Simonet (2008) for further explanation of the reduced nuclear rise in Peninsular Spanish declarative statements.

In order to understand better the H1 alignment difference in milliseconds, percentage scores were converted to milliseconds. H1 aligned at the 67 ms point in statements and the 115 ms point in questions (average). This difference was 48 ms. The later alignment in questions may be due to the fact that H1 was more difficult to label in the early rise contour, since there was no clear peak before the nuclear rise.

In order to understand better the H1 alignment difference in milliseconds, percentage scores were converted to milliseconds. H1 aligned at the 82 ms point in statements and the 97 ms point in questions (average). This difference was 15 ms.

It is important to bear in mind that not all speakers conformed to the general trend that statement peaks were at the same level of question peaks. For example, speaker 8M showed higher peaks in questions than statements, whereas speakers 5F and 7F showed higher peaks in statements than questions.

The specific finding was that of the 16 speakers recorded, 10 speakers produced the late rise more frequently in the reading task, whereas 11 speakers produced the early rise more frequently in the dialogue task. Also, ‘speech style’ was understood within a sociolinguistic framework, with the choice of speaking very formally or informally being governed by the speaking circumstances or the situation of use. For further information, see Bell (1984, 1997) or Labov (1966, 1972, 1994).
